prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for taking my 3yo out to do something fun whilst my partner is at work?
I will try and keep this short . 

Almost every weekend when I say lets take our kid out to the play centre or a farm ect I get one of maybe 3  excuses every time without fail . Either "I dont want to go out / I just wanna sit and play on the computer. " " ive been at work im tired I don't wanna go out / drive " or " I don't wanna spend the money on x, y ,z" ( we have money so its not like thats a real problem )   

Today a friend asked me if i wanted to go with her with the kids to the farm near us tomorrow and I said yes . I figured since we hadn't taken little one anywhere fun for a few weeks it would be nice . 

So I mentioned it to my partner and he goes off on one about how its not fair as he is at work and he would like to go blah blah . I said so I cant take her anywhere when you're at work ? Pointed out that I asked to go not a week or two earlier and was told no its too expencive and  I dont want to go out I'm tired. ( its £7 each ). 

So now he wants me to cancle with my friend so he can go another day . I said we can go whenever you want . But apparently thats not an option either . 

Its a childrens petting zoo ffs its not like im going to see a movie wothout him. 
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking if the person who wrote the scenario is in the wrong for taking their 3-year-old out to a fun activity while their partner is at work. 

First, the partner has consistently refused to go out on weekends, giving excuses like being tired, not wanting to spend money (even though they can afford it), or not feeling like driving. The author decided to go with a friend to a farm, which is a kids' activity, and the partner is upset because he's at work and wants to go another day.

So, the author's actions: They took the initiative to plan something for the child, considering the partner's previous refusals. The partner is now upset about being excluded. The key points here are about shared responsibility in parenting and fairness.

The author isn't going to a movie by themselves; it's a family-friendly event with the child and a friend. The partner's reaction seems to be about not wanting to miss out, but the author has already tried to involve him before, which he declined. The cost is minimal (£7 each), so money isn't a real issue. 

From a fairness perspective, both parents should share in childcare responsibilities. However, the partner has been avoiding these outings, so maybe the author is right to step in. The partner's sudden objection when it's the author's turn to take the child might be about his own feelings of exclusion rather than the child's needs. 

The author isn't doing anything harmful; they're giving the child an enriching experience. The partner's excuses seem to be more about his own preferences than the child's well-being. So, the author isn't in the wrong for making a decision that benefits the child, especially after repeated refusals from the partner. The answer would be B (No).
